Despite these challenges, however, it is becoming clear that developing new TB vaccines is an achievable goal. The partially protective effect of BCG, capable of preventing up to 80% of cases of severe, disseminated TB in infants and young children, provides important supportive evidence of this point. Additional evidence comes from the 90% of Mtb-infected persons who are capable of controlling their infection throughout their lives without developing disease; and the intriguing examples of individuals at high risk of Mtb infection who, when assessed for Mtb infection by TST or IGRA, demonstrate transient positivity on repeated assessments before reverting to a consistently negative state, a situation with unclear clinical significance but which has been interpreted by some as evidence of early immunological containment of Mtb infection and a reduced risk of TB disease
14â€“ 17 . Examples of individuals with lifelong exposure to Mtb, through household or occupational contact, for example, who never convert their TSTs or IGRAs, may represent another example of natural immunity to Mtb that a vaccine could be able to replicate or improve upon
18 .
